H0.text: Meter is the unit of measurement that astronomers use when measuring the distance between two stars found in the Milky Way.

H1.text: Light‑year is the unit of measurement astronomers use when measuring the distance between two stars found in the Milky Way.

H2.text: Kilometers are the unit of measurement astronomers use when measuring the distance between two stars found in the Milky Way.

H3.text: The astronomical unit is the unit of measurement astronomers use when measuring the distance between two stars found in the Milky Way.

A4.text: The light‑year is most often used when expressing distances to stars and other distances on a galactic scale.

A5.text: The unit most commonly used in professional astronomy is the parsec (symbol: pc, about 3.26 light‑years).

A6.text: The parsec unit is obtained by the use of parallax and trigonometry, and is defined as the distance at which 1 AU subtends an angle of one arcsecond.

A7.text: The parsec (symbol: pc) is a unit of length used to measure the large distances to astronomical objects outside the Solar System, approximately equal to 3.26 light-years or 206,265 astronomical units (AU), i.e. 30.9 trillion kilometres (19.2 trillion miles).
